titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Harriet L. Clark Collection 1818-2001 MS010 MS010 MS010
titlestmt.author: Processed by Ryan Bachman

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2017-02-02 07:51:52 -0800.

did.abstract: This collection contains items relating to East Cornwall native Harriet Lydia Clark (1894-1997).

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: This collection is made up of items that Clark both collected and wrote during her lifetime.

archdesc.userestrict:
Use Restrictions Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the:
Research library
Cornwall Historical Society
7 Pine Street

Cornwall, CT 06753
Phone: 860-672-0505
E-mail: CornHistSoc@optonline.net

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); The Harriet L. Clark Collection; MS010; box number; folder number; Cornwall Historical Society

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Harriet Lydia Clark (1894-1997) was descended from some of the earliest settlers in Cornwall, and maintained an interest in the history of both her family and community during her career as an educator and politician. She was born in East Cornwall to Andrew Miles Clark and Mary Brown Clark on November 11, 1894. After receiving degrees from both Boston University and Columbia University, Clark began a teaching career that took her to schools in locations such as East Cornwall, Warren, Goshen, and Danbury. Following her retirement from teaching, Clark was elected to the Connecticut House of Representatives in 1956, and represented Cornwall at the state assembly until 1965. Clark was a prolific genealogist and writer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This collection is made up of six archival boxes. The first box contains bound items that belonged to the Clark family, and are organized in chronological order. The second box contains historic items relating to the Cornwall Clark family, as well as letters written by East Cornwall native Augustus White in 1852. White left East Cornwall to search for gold in California in 1852, and the letters he sent back to his family and friends in Connecticut detail his journey to the mining towns outside of San Francisco. The third box of this collection contains personal and memorial items of Harriet Clark, such as letters, and the fourth box contains publications that she wrote. The final two boxes contain scrapbooks compiled by Clark relating to her time as a state representative and her personal interest in the Foreign Mission School.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Folders are arranged chronologically within each series.
The files are grouped into 5 series:
